image.altText: A group of people standing with umbrellas and signs on a wet concrete floor outside a building in the Sydney CBD.

items.synopsis: Around two dozen protesters have gathered outside the RBA's headquarters in Sydney ahead of this afternoon's interest rate decision, while trade on the Australian share market remains steady. Follow live.

title.children: Protesters gather outside Reserve Bank ahead of interest rates decision, ASX steady

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank has held the cash rate at the current level of 4.1%. Economists were divided on whether the RBA would lift or hold.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: RBA keeps interest rates on at 4.1pc

children.content: The Reserve Bank has held the cash rate at the current level of 4.1%.
Economists were divided on whether the RBA would lift or hold.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ahead of this afternoon's decision by the RBA, here's a quick refresher of where the current cash rate sits. With a rate of 4.1% as of June, the cash rate is currently the highest it's been since April 2012. Should the RBA lift interest rates by 0.25 percentage points at 2:30pm AEST, it would be take the cash rate to 4.35%, and would make it the highest rate since November 2011 (which is more than 11-and-a-half years ago). Here's the history of the cash rate since 1990 — as you can see, when we look at the data from more than 30 years, the recent rate hikes are certainly steep compared to past increases.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What does the current cash rate look like?

children.content: Ahead of this afternoon's decision by the RBA, here's a quick refresher of where the current cash rate sits.
With a rate of 4.1% as of June, the cash rate is currently
the highest it's been since April 2012
Should the RBA lift interest rates by 0.25 percentage points at 2:30pm AEST, it would be take the
cash rate to 4.35%
, and would make it the highest rate since
November 2011
(which is more than 11-and-a-half years ago).
Here's the history of the cash rate since 1990 — as you can see, when we look at the data from more than 30 years, the recent rate hikes are certainly steep compared to past increases.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's not just economists that are divided over what the RBA will decide to do with interest rates this month — so too are the big four banks. Here's what they're expecting the RBA to decide this afternoon: ANZ: 0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35% Westpac: 0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35 NAB: 0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35 Commonwealth Bank: hold at current rate of 4.1% Chief economists at all the big banks say it's becoming increasingly hard to predict just what the RBA will decide to do. For a summary of their thinking, follow this link to one of David's earlier posts .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: This is what the big four banks think the RBA will do with interest rates

children.content: It's not just economists that are divided over what the RBA will decide to do with interest rates this month — so too are the big four banks.
Here's what they're expecting the RBA to decide this afternoon:
ANZ:
0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35%
Westpac:
0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35
NAB:
0.25 percentage point increase to 4.35
Commonwealth Bank:
hold at current rate of 4.1%
Chief economists at all the big banks say it's becoming increasingly hard to predict just what the RBA will decide to do.
For a summary of their thinking,
follow this link to one of David's earlier posts

title.children: 'Same old Aussies, always winning': Albo fires back at British PM over Ashes dismissal furore

image.altText: An elderly woman with glasses smiling with a flower border. An elderly man with glasses smiling.

items.synopsis: A woman related to a 94-year-old woman and her husband, who died in hospital a year apart, has now been charged with two counts of murder after she was arrested earlier today, SA police say.

title.children: Female relative charged with murders of couple, both 94, who died a year apart

image.altText: A composite photo of Dr Karishma Dahia on the left and Laura Vissaritis on the right

items.synopsis: Join dog behaviourist Laura Vissaritis and vet Dr Karishma Dahia as they tackle some of your curly canine questions in our live Q&A.

title.children: Is your dog postie-obsessed or an excessive barker? Join our experts as they troubleshoot your canine challenges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Stephen: How do we break a habit, a habit that does come and go,      of weeing in the house? Heidi: Why would my rescue dog suddenly wee on my bed right where I sleep? She is well trained, has no notable history of abuse and has been a delight to welcome into our home. Thanks Stephen and Heidi for you questions! I've put this to both Dr Karishma and Laura V. Dr Karishma: Breaking habits, especially ones that are intermittent can be a challenging and lengthy process. The first step is trying to identify the trigger for this behaviour. Some common reasons include territorial spraying if they are not desexed, from urinary incontinence, old age, osteoarthritis, dementia, stress/fear/anxiety - even to noise outside, kidney disease, diabetes, cushing's disease, or urinary tract infections/stones in the bladder. It's important to get your pet checked at the vet to identify any of these underlying issues. Once a trigger has been identified, it usually will make things easier to treat, especially if there is an underlying medical issue. If these things have been ruled out, then re-training your dog may include things like increasing toilet breaks - especially after sleep and rewarding them for peeing in appropriate places. As well as ensuring area's where they have previously urinated are thoroughly cleaned with an enzymatic cleaner that eliminates the smell so they can't recognoise that smell.And considering pheromone collars and diffuser's in the house to help they feel comfortable in their environment if they are an anxious dog. And here's Laura V's take: Laura V: Dogs will wee inside the house for a number of reasons - they have not been trained properly to go outdoors, or they have an underlying anxiety, or they have an underlying medical problem. If it is occasional, try to identify the pattern. If you can predict it, then you can prevent it, by calling your dog outside to the toilet. Putting your dog on a lead can also help as you can manage their behaviour more consistently, preventing them from sneaking away to wee in another room. There is always the possibility that your dog has an underlying infection or disease that needs to be addressed by your vet, so a check up is well worth it. Punishing dogs for having accidents inside only makes them more anxious and can make them more likely to sneak away in another room when you're not looking.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How do we break a habit, a habit that does come and go, of weeing in the house?

How do we break a habit, a habit that does come and go,      of weeing in the house?

Dr Karishma
and
Laura V.
Dr Karishma:
Breaking habits, especially ones that are intermittent can be a challenging and lengthy process. The first step is trying to
identify the trigger
for this behaviour.

Some common reasons include territorial spraying if they are not desexed, from urinary incontinence, old age, osteoarthritis, dementia, stress/fear/anxiety - even to noise outside, kidney disease, diabetes, cushing's disease, or urinary tract infections/stones in the bladder.
It's important to get your pet checked at the vet to identify any of these
underlying
issues.
Once a trigger has been identified, it usually will make things easier to treat, especially if there is an underlying medical issue. If these things have
been ruled out, then re-training your dog may include things like
increasing
toilet breaks
- especially after sleep and rewarding them for peeing in appropriate places. As well as ensuring area's where they have previously urinated are thoroughly cleaned with an enzymatic
cleaner that eliminates the smell so they can't recognoise that smell.And considering pheromone collars and diffuser's
in the house to help they feel comfortable in their environment if they are an anxious dog.
And here's
Laura V's
take:
Laura V:
Dogs will wee inside
the house for a number of reasons - they have not been trained properly
to go outdoors, or they have an underlying anxiety, or they have an underlying medical problem. If it is occasional, try to
identify
the pattern

. If you can predict it, then you can prevent it, by calling your dog outside to the toilet. Putting your dog on a lead can also help as you can manage their behaviour more consistently, preventing them from sneaking away to wee in another room.
There is always the possibility that your dog has an
underlying infection or disease
that needs to be addressed by your vet, so a check up is well worth it. Punishing dogs for having accidents inside only makes them more anxious and can make them more likely
to sneak away in another room when you're not looking.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Luke: Hello! Our greyhound daisy      gets lots of love and attention. We take her for at least 1 walk but it      seems no matter what we do she still digs up our yard. Any advice? Thanks for your question Luke! Yard-digging is another one of those universal behaviours that seem to be tricky to navigate. Here's Laura V 's take: Laura V: When does she dig? When you're not home? Does she dig if she has access to indoors (as in, if she is unable to get inside, does this stimulate the behaviour)? Sometimes dogs will dig to alleviate stress, but other times, they are doing normal dog stuff. Digging has an important role in canine behaviour. So, it may have nothing to do with how much exercise she is getting. It may be about how she is feeling when she is outside. Once you can answer this question, you can begin to address the behaviour. We always want to discover the cause of a behaviour before trying to change it. And, if the behaviour is not bothering your dog, a place to dig may be of value to her. Sometimes problem behaviours are behaviours that bother us, not our dog. This is an important distinction to make.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How to reduce dog digging and yard destruction?

children.content: Luke:
Hello! Our greyhound daisy      gets lots of love and attention. We take her for at least 1 walk but it      seems no matter what we do she still digs up our yard. Any advice?
Thanks for your question Luke! Yard-digging is another one of those universal behaviours that seem to be tricky to navigate.
Here's
Laura V
's take:
Laura V:
When does she dig? When you're not home? Does she dig if she has access to indoors
(as in, if she is unable to get inside, does this stimulate the behaviour)? Sometimes dogs
will dig to
alleviate stress
, but other times, they are doing
normal dog stuff.
Digging has an important role in canine behaviour. So, it may have nothing to do with how much exercise she is getting. It may be about how she is feeling when she is outside.
Once you can answer this question, you can begin to address the behaviour. We always want to discover the
cause of a behaviour

before trying to change it. And, if the behaviour is not bothering your dog, a place to dig may be of value to her. Sometimes problem behaviours are behaviours that bother us, not our dog. This is an important distinction to make.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Tom : I'm potentially going to adopt a senior dog (8 yrs) who has an issue with resource guarding on items/food she thinks is hers. Given her age is resource guarding able to be fixed? Is it difficult? Would I need to get a professional trainer? I have read that resource guarding gets worst with age. Alice : How do I stop my dog from resource guarding? Steve : How do you teach a dog how to stop resource guarding? He is fine most of the time, but as soon as he guards something, it's like a switch has been flicked. We try and remove everything off the floor, but sometimes he finds even a clothes peg to guard. Thank you. Resource guarding is another topic that's come up a bit so thank you all for your questions. Here's Laura V 's advice: Laura V: Guarding a resource is generally motivated by the fear of losing that valued item. This can cause dogs a great deal of distress, so it is really important we don't threaten our dogs, as this can be unsafe for all involved. If it is food, teach your dog that there is a room where the food is given. Close the door and allow the dog to eat their food in peace. Never try to take the food away. If your dog is a puppy and you're wanting to prevent this guarding behaviour, walking past your dog's bowl should result in you adding food to the bowl, not taking the food away. If your dog guards other items such as balls or even people, it is critical that we remove the need to feel that way. i.e. have two balls where you can exchange one for the other. For guarding people, I'd recommend getting some professional help. The reason for this is that we are dealing with some very heightened emotions, that need to be addressed gently from someone experienced in the field.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How do I stop my dog from resource guarding?

try to take the food away. If your dog is a puppy and you're wanting to prevent this guarding behaviour,
walking past your dog's bowl
should result in you adding food to the bowl, not taking the food away.
If your dog guards other items such as balls or even people, it is critical that we remove the need to feel that way. i.e. have two balls where you can exchange
one for the other. For guarding people, I'd recommend getting some professional help. The reason for this is that we are dealing with some very
heightened emotions
, that need to be addressed gently from someone experienced in the field.

image.altText: A composite image of two men of Chinese appearance.

items.synopsis: Two men living in Australia have criticised a move by Hong Kong authorities to issue them with arrest warrants under a controversial national security law, putting a $HK1 million bounty on their heads.

title.children: Adelaide man says warrant for his arrest in Hong Kong shows China is 'more a threat than a friend to the world'

image.altText: A person takes a photo as a full moon known as the "Buck Moon" rises behind the Temple of Poseidon, in Cape Sounion, near Athens

items.synopsis: Don't stress if the cloudy weather locked you out of last night's supermoon — there's three more before the end of the year.

title.children: Clouds blocked the buck supermoon for many in Australia, so here's photos of it from around the world

image.altText: Police tape across a fence and gate.

items.synopsis: A pet dog was killed in an alleged home invasion in Forest Lake, after three men allegedly tried to coax the residents of the home outside by taking the dog hostage.

title.children: Alleged Brisbane home invaders stabbed pet dog in bid to coax residents outside, police say

image.altText: A dad and two young children play on equipment in a waterpark.

items.synopsis: Record-breaking winter rain is sweeping across Queensland, keeping temperatures low — but the far north will soon be in for a scorcher.

title.children: 'Only good for a duck': Unusual winter wet to make way for warmer weather in the north

image.altText: Heather Anderson portrait

items.synopsis: Adelaide premiership player Heather Anderson is the first known professional female athlete to be diagnosed with the degenerative brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE).

title.children: 'Highly significant': First professional female athlete diagnosed with CTE in landmark case

image.altText: A soldier waves a Ukrainian flag with his right hand as he holds a rifle in his left hand while standing atop a concrete block.

items.synopsis: While many fret about the "slowness" of the Ukrainian campaign, all military operations consist of pulses and pauses and there is much we do not see in this war. It is important to remain patient, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Ukraine's war campaign may seem 'slow', but its strategy is full of surprises — and Russia could be in trouble

image.altText: RBA governor Philip Lowe speaks at the Morgan Stanley Australia summit in Sydney

items.synopsis: With the economy slowing, inflation pressures easing and household expenditure diving, starting the new financial year with hike number 13 could well prove to be an ominous sign, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Abandon all logic — whether the RBA pauses rates comes down to a coin toss

image.altText: A missing person poster of a Hispanic teenage boy, showing his name and a table with descriptive information.

items.synopsis: Police say Rudy Farias was discovered unconscious outside a church in Houston, Texas, eight years after he went missing.

title.children: Teen who vanished while walking dogs in 2015 found unconscious outside Texas church

image.altText: A man wearing a black jacket, plaid shirt and black beanie holds an acoustic guitar.

items.synopsis: What started off as a casually recorded folk song became a foundational entry in the Australian songbook.

title.children: It began with some chords strummed around a camp fire before becoming an Australian music legacy

image.altText: A black-and-white image of a circus performer with a modern-day image of a man in Toreador costume.

items.synopsis: Almost a century after the "greatest tightwire artist of all time" built his career on hiding his Indigenous heritage, Con Colleano's legacy is celebrated through a special tribute in his home town.

title.children: He fooled Hitler and Mussolini, now Lismore celebrates local highwire hero Con Colleano

image.altText: the president of indonesia arrives at an airport as he is greeted by officials

items.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong flags a relaxation of visa rules for some Indonesians, as the country's president arrives in Sydney for bilateral talks.

title.children: Easing of visa rules for Indonesians flagged as president arrives in Sydney

image.altText: Chief Superintendent of Police Li Kwai-wah speaks during a press conference.

items.synopsis: An Australian citizen is among eight overseas-based activists who have been accused by Hong Kong police of national security offences, including foreign collusion and incitement to secession.

title.children: Australian lawyer has $190k reward offered against him by Hong Kong authorities

image.altText: a woman looking at facebook marketplace on a computer

items.synopsis: Ever sold something on Facebook Marketplace or Gumtree? Without knowing it, you might've put yourself in danger. Here's how to stay safe when selling items online.

title.children: Seller beware: How putting up items for sale on Facebook Marketplace and Gumtree could put you at risk

image.altText: A collection of maneki-neko or lucky cat statues.

items.synopsis: Maneki-neko — otherwise known as lucky cats or welcoming cats — are found around the world. But where the ceramic cats began to be sold remains a mystery, writes Tets Kimura.

title.children: They're now found behind cash registers all over the world, but where did the beckoning cat come from?

image.altText: A dog being assessed at the vet, close up of dog's face

items.synopsis: As people shy away from professional help due to tightening household budgets, vets are seeing the all-too-real consequences for suffering pets.

title.children: Pet owners warned against 'playing vet' amid cost-of-living crisis

image.altText: A man in a black suit stands next to a woman in a floral print dress

title.children: Robert De Niro's grandson, Leandro De Niro Rodriguez, dies at 19

image.altText: A photo of a car being driven at night with a blurry night trail.

items.synopsis: Victoria's road toll is at a 12-year high. A driver, who spent time in jail after he killed another person while speeding, shares his story in the hope others don't make a similar mistake.

image.altText: A composite image of Novak Djokovic and Jordan Thompson

image.altText: group of people sitting around a bushfire

title.children: Road closures, muddy chaos for travellers heading to Birdsville's Big Red Bash
